frontmatter.title: Reducing the uncertainty about the uncertainties, part 2: Frames and manifolds

children.value: we discussed some basic concepts to solve linear and nonlinear factor graphs and to extract uncertainty estimates from them. We reviewed that the Fisher information matrix corresponds to an approximation of the inverse covariance of the solution, and that in the nonlinear case, both the solution and its covariance estimate are
valid for the current linearization point only
While the nonlinear case effectively allows us to model a bunch of problems, we need to admit we were not too honest when we said that it was
we needed to model real problems. Our formulation so far assumed that the variables in our factor graph are
, which is not the case for robotics and computer vision at least.
This second part will review the concept of

and how the reference frames affect the formulation of our factor graph. The tools we cover here will be also useful to define probability distributions in a more general way, as well as to extend our estimation framework to more general problems.
In robotics we do not estimate the state of a robot only by their position
. Then we say that is its
, i.e position and orientation together, what matters to define its state.
Representing pose is a tricky thing. We could say
“ok, but let’s just append the orientation to the position vector and do everything as before”
but that does not work in practice. Problem arises when we want to compose two poses

children.html: T1=(x1,y1,θ1)\mathbf{T}_1 = (x_1, y_1, \theta_1)T1​=(x1​,y1​,θ1​)
T2=(x2,y2,θ2)\mathbf{T}_2 = (x_2, y_2, \theta_2)T2​=(x2​,y2​,θ2​)

children.value: . Under the vector assumption, we can write the following expression as the composition of two poses:

\mathbf{T}_1 + \mathbf{T}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ y_1 \\ \theta_1 \end{bmatrix}  +  \begin{bmatrix} x_2 \\ y_2 \\ \theta_2\end{bmatrix}  = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 + x_2 \\ y_1+y_2 \\ \theta_1 + \theta_2\end{bmatrix}
children.html: T1+T2=[x1y1θ1]+[x2y2θ2]=[x1+x2y1+y2θ1+θ2]\mathbf{T}_1 + \mathbf{T}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ y_1 \\ \theta_1 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} x_2 \\ y_2 \\ \theta_2\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 + x_2 \\ y_1+y_2 \\ \theta_1 + \theta_2\end{bmatrix}T1​+T2​=⎣⎡​x1​y1​θ1​​⎦⎤​+⎣⎡​x2​y2​θ2​​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​x1​+x2​y1​+y2​θ1​+θ2​​⎦⎤​

children.value: it does not matter if we start in pose

children.html: T1\mathbf{T}_1T1​
T2\mathbf{T}_2T2​

children.value: , we will end up at the same final pose
by composing both, because in vector spaces we can commute the elements.
But this does not work in reality, because rotations and translations do not commute
. A simple example is that if you are currently sitting at your desk,  and you
stand up, rotate 180 degrees and walk a step forward
stand up, walk a step forward and then rotate 180 degrees
(apart from the fact that you will hit your desk if you do the latter).
So we need a different representation for poses that allow us to describe accurately what we observe in reality. Long story short, we rather have to represent planar poses as

children.html: 3×33\times33×3

T1=[cos⁡θ1−sin⁡θ1x1sin⁡θ1cos⁡θ1y1001]=[R1t101]\mathbf{T}_1 = \left[\begin{matrix} \cos{\theta_1} && -\sin{\theta_1} && x_1 \\ \sin{\theta_1} && \cos{\theta_1} && y_1 \\ 0 && 0 && 1\end{matrix} \right] = \left[\begin{matrix} \mathbf{R}_1 && \mathbf{t}_1 \\ 0 && 1\end{matrix}\right]T1​=⎣⎡​cosθ1​sinθ1​0​​−sinθ1​cosθ1​0​​x1​y1​1​⎦⎤​=[R1​0​​t1​1​]
R1=[cos⁡θ1−sin⁡θ1sin⁡θ1cos⁡θ1]\mathbf{R}_1 = \left[ \begin{matrix} \cos{\theta_1} && -\sin{\theta_1}\\ \sin{\theta_1} && \cos{\theta_1}\end{matrix} \right]R1​=[cosθ1​sinθ1​​​−sinθ1​cosθ1​​]
t1=[x1y1]\mathbf{t}_1 = \left[ \begin{matrix}x_1 \\ y_1 \end{matrix}\right]t1​=[x1​y1​​]

children.value:
is a translation vector.
While we are using a

children.html: 3×33\times33×3

children.value: matrix now to represent the pose,
, since it is a function of

children.html: (x1,y1,θ1)(x_1, y_1, \theta_1)(x1​,y1​,θ1​)

children.value: Working with transformation matrices is great, because we can now describe the behavior we previously explained with words using matrix operations. If we start in pose

children.html: T1\mathbf{T}_1T1​
T2\mathbf{T}_2T2​

T1T2=[R1t101][R2t201]=[R1R2R1t2+t101]\mathbf{T}_1 \mathbf{T}_2 = \left[\begin{matrix} \mathbf{R}_1 && \mathbf{t}_1 \\ 0 && 1\end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix} \mathbf{R}_2 && \mathbf{t}_2 \\ 0 && 1\end{matrix}\right] = \left[\begin{matrix} \mathbf{R}_1 \mathbf{R}_2 && \mathbf{R}_1 \mathbf{t}_2 + \mathbf{t}_1 \\ 0 && 1\end{matrix}\right]T1​T2​=[R1​0​​t1​1​][R2​0​​t2​1​]=[R1​R2​0​​R1​t2​+t1​1​]

children.value: We can now rewrite the same problem as before but now using our transformation matrices:

children.html: Ti+1=Ti ΔTi\mathbf{T}_{i+1} = \mathbf{T}_i \ \Delta\mathbf{T}_iTi+1​=Ti​ ΔTi​

children.value: Here we are saying that the next state

children.html: Ti+1\mathbf{T}_{i+1}Ti+1​

children.value: is gonna be the previous state

children.html: Ti\mathbf{T}_{i}Ti​
ΔTi\Delta\mathbf{T}_iΔTi​

children.value: given by a sensor -odometry in this case. Please note that since we are now working with transformation matrices,

children.html: ΔTi\Delta\mathbf{T}_iΔTi​

children.value: is almost everything we need to model the problem more accurately, since it will represent a change in both position and orientation.
there are two things here that we must discuss
before moving on, which are fundamental to make everything consistent. We will review them carefully now.
While some people (myself included) prefer to write the process as we did before, applying the increment on the

children.html: Ti+1=Ti ΔTi\mathbf{T}_{i+1} = \mathbf{T}_i \ \Delta\mathbf{T}_iTi+1​=Ti​ ΔTi​

children.value: Others do it in a different way, on the

children.html: Ti+1=ΔTi Ti\mathbf{T}_{i+1} = \Delta\mathbf{T}_i \ \mathbf{T}_iTi+1​=ΔTi​ Ti​

children.value: These expressions are not equivalent as we already discussed because rigid-body transformations do not commute. However,
both make sense under specific conventions
. We will be more explicit now by introducing the concept of
in our notation. We will use the notation presented by Paul Furgale in his blog post
“Representing Robot Pose: The good, the bad, and the ugly”
Let us say that the robot trajectory in space is expressed in a fixed frame; we will called it the

children.html: WWW

children.value: . The robot itself defines a coordinate frame in its body, the

children.html: BBB
BBB
WWW
TWB\mathbf{T}_{WB}TWB​
WWW
BBB
TBW\mathbf{T}_{BW}TBW​

children.value: According to this formulation, the first is a description
while the left-hand one does it
. The interesting thing is that we can always go from one to the other by inverting the matrices:

children.html: TWB−1=TBW\mathbf{T}_{WB}^{-1} = \mathbf{T}_{BW}TWB−1​=TBW​

children.value: Using one or the other does not matter. The important thing is to stay consistent

.
In fact, by making the frames explicit in our convention we can always check if we are making mistakes. Let us say we are using the first definition, and our odometer is providing increments
relative to the previous body state

ΔTBiBi+1\Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1} }ΔTBi​Bi+1​​

children.value: We know this is correct because the inner indices cancel each other, effectively representing the pose at

children.html: i+1i+1i+1
TWBi+1=TWBi ΔTBiBi+1\mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} = \mathbf{T}_{W {\bcancel{B_i}} } \ \Delta\mathbf{T}_{ {\bcancel{B_{i}}} B_{i+1} }TWBi+1​​=TWBi​​​ ΔTBi​​Bi+1​​

, we will refer to this as the

When using right-hand convention, the increments to describe the pose of the robot at instant $i$ are applied on the right-hand side. All our estimates are expressed with respect to a fixed world frame $W$ (in black).
If we want to apply the increment to

children.html: TBW\mathbf{T}_{BW}TBW​

children.value: , we would need to invert the measurement:

children.html: ΔTBi+1Bi=ΔTBiBi+1−1\Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i+1} B_{i}} = \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}}^{-1}ΔTBi+1​Bi​​=ΔTBi​Bi+1​−1​

children.value: so we can apply the transformation

children.html: TBi+1W=ΔTBi+1BiTBiW\mathbf{T}_{B_{i+1}W} = \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i+1} B_{i}} \mathbf{T}_{B_i W}TBi+1​W​=ΔTBi+1​Bi​​TBi​W​

children.value: which we will refer onward as
With left-hand convention the increments are applied from the left, changing our reference frame to the new robot pose $B_{i+1}$ (in black) .
In GTSAM we use the right-hand convention: we assume that the variables are expressed with respect to a fixed frame

children.html: WWW

children.value: , hence the increments are applied on the right-hand side

It is important to have this in mind because all the operations that are implemented follow this. As a matter of fact, 3D computer vision has generally used left-hand convention because it is straightforward to apply the projection models from the left:

children.html: Ip=KIC TCW WP{_I}\mathbf{p} = \mathbf{K}_{IC}\ \mathbf{T}_{CW}\ {_{W}}\mathbf{P}I​p=KIC​ TCW​ W​P

children.value: Here we made explicit all the frames involved in the transformations we usually can find in textbooks: An homogeneous point

children.html: WP{_{W}}\mathbf{P}W​P
WWW
TCW\mathbf{T}_{CW}TCW​

children.value: (a rigid body transformation ) which represents the world

children.html: WWW
CCC
CP{_{C}}\mathbf{P}C​P

children.value: in the camera frame (not shown). This is projected onto the image by means of the intrinsic calibration matrix

children.html: KIC\mathbf{K}_{IC}KIC​
Ip_I\mathbf{p}I​p
III

children.value: Since in GTSAM the extrinsic calibration is defined the other way to be consistent with the right-hand convention, i.e

children.html: TWC\mathbf{T}_{WC}TWC​

children.value: properly inverting the matrix before doing the projection

children.html: Ip=KIC (TWC)−1 WP{_I}\mathbf{p} = \mathbf{K}_{IC}\ (\mathbf{T}_{WC})^{-1}\ {_{W}}\mathbf{P}I​p=KIC​ (TWC​)−1 W​P

children.value: The second important point we need to discuss, is that while rigid-body transformations are nice, the new expression we have to represent the process presents some challenges when trying to use it in our factor graph using our previous method:

children.html: TWBi+1=TWBi ΔTBiBi+1\mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} = \mathbf{T}_{WB_i} \ \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1} }TWBi+1​​=TWBi​​ ΔTBi​Bi+1​​

children.value: In first place, we need to figure out a way to include the

children.html: ηi\eta_iηi​

children.value: we used before to handle the uncertainties about our measurement

children.html: ΔTBiBi+1\Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1} }ΔTBi​Bi+1​​

children.value: we used to generate the Gaussian factors we use in our factor graph. For now, we will say that the noise will be given by a matrix

children.html: Ni∈R4×4\mathbf{N}_i \in \mathbb{R}^{4\times4}Ni​∈R4×4
TWBi+1=TWBi ΔTBiBi+1Ni\mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} = \mathbf{T}_{WB_i} \ \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}} \mathbf{N}_iTWBi+1​​=TWBi​​ ΔTBi​Bi+1​​Ni​
Ni\mathbf{N}_iNi​

children.value: was defined somehow, we can isolate it as we did before. However, we need to use matrix operations now:

children.html: Ni=(TWBi ΔTBiBi+1)−1TWBi+1\mathbf{N}_i = (\mathbf{T}_{WB_i} \ \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}})^{-1} \mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}}Ni​=(TWBi​​ ΔTBi​Bi+1​​)−1TWBi+1​​

children.value: and we can manipulate it a bit for clarity:

children.html: Ni=(ΔTBiBi+1)−1(TWBi)−1TWBi+1\mathbf{N}_i = (\Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}})^{-1} (\mathbf{T}_{WB_i})^{-1} \mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}}Ni​=(ΔTBi​Bi+1​​)−1(TWBi​​)−1TWBi+1​​

children.value: If we do the subindex cancelation trick we did before, properly swapping the indices due to the inverses, we can confirm that the error is defined

children.html: Bi+1B_{i+1}Bi+1​
Bi+1B_{i+1}Bi+1​

children.value: . This may seen counterintuitive, but in fact describes what we want: the degree of mismatch between our models and measurements to express the pose at frame

children.html: Bi+1B_{i+1}Bi+1​

children.value: However, the error is still a matrix, which is impossible to include as a factor in the framework we have built so far. We cannot compute a
as we did before, nor we are completely sure that the matrix

children.html: Ni\mathbf{N}_iNi​

children.value: follows some sort of Gaussian distribution.
We need to define some important concepts used in GTSAM to get a better understanding on how the objects are manipulated.
First of all, some objects used in GTSAM are
) and quaternions, and of course vector spaces (
) have some basic operations that allow us to manipulate them. These concepts
have been discussed in previous posts
: How to compose 2 objects from the same manifold, with associativity properties. It is similar to the
: An identity operator under the composition/between.
: An element that when composed with its inverse becomes the identity.
The previous 3 operations allows us to define the operation
, which computes the difference between 2 objects from the same group, similarly to a

Since the operations can be defined in different ways for each kind of object (it is different to compose rotation matrices than quaternions or vectors for instance), some authors define special operators to refer to composition/between operations. Some examples are the

children.html: ⊞\boxplus⊞
⊟\boxminus⊟

children.value: However, composition can be defined from the
composition is associative but is not distributive
. This is the same problem we described before when talking about reference frames and how to add small increments with the

hand conventions, since both are valid depending on our decisions or other authors’. While we can be clear about our own decisions, it is important to be aware of the definitions of each author because sometimes are not clearly stated.
for example make the difference explicit by defining

children.html: ⊕\oplus⊕
⊕\oplus⊕

children.value: respectively, but we need to be careful to recognize each other’s choices.
We recall again that in GTSAM and the rest of this post we use the
), because we represent our poses with respect to a fixed world frame

children.html: WWW

children.value: and the increments are defined with respect to the body frame

children.html: BBB

children.value: Additionally, rigid-body transformations, rotation matrices, quaternions and even vectors are
. This means that even though they do not behave as Euclidean spaces at a global scale, they can be
as such by using local vector spaces called
. The main advantage of analyzing all these objects from the manifold perspective is that we can build general algorithms based on common principles that apply to all of them.

While a manifold have a non-Euclidean structure, it can be locally approximated by tangent spaces. In the figure, we illustrate different tangent spaces defined at the objects $\mathbf{p}_1$ and $\mathbf{p}_2$ on the manifold.
As we briefly mentioned before, objects such as rotation matrices are difficult to manipulate in the estimation framework because they are matrices. A 3D rotation matrix

children.html: R\mathbf{R}R

children.value: represents 3 orientations with respect to a reference frame but, in raw terms, they are using 9 values to do so, which seems to
the object. However, the constraints that define a rotation matrix -and consequently the manifold- such as orthonormality

children.html: RTR=I\mathbf{R}^{T}\mathbf{R} = \mathbf{I}RTR=I
det(R)=1\text{det}(\mathbf{R}) = 1det(R)=1

children.value: make the inherent dimensionality of the rotation still 3. Interestingly, this is
exactly the dimensionality of the tangent spaces that can be defined over the manifold
That is what makes working with manifolds so convenient
: All the constraints that are part of the definition of the object are naturally handled, and we can work in tangent vector spaces using their
dimension. The same happens for rigid-body transformations (6 dimensions represented by a 16 elements matrix), quaternions (3 orientations represented by a 4D vector),
and even objects that are not groups, such as unit vectors
In order to work with manifolds, we need to define 2 operations, which are the key to transform objects between them and the tangent spaces:

children.html: ξ\mathbf{\xi}ξ
p1\mathbf{p}_1p1​
p=retractp1(ξ)\mathbf{p} = \text{retract}_{\mathbf{p}_1}(\mathbf{\xi})p=retractp1​​(ξ)
p\mathbf{p}p

children.value: from the manifold to the tangent space

children.html: ξ=localp1(p)\mathbf{\xi} = \text{local}_{\mathbf{p}_1}(\mathbf{p})ξ=localp1​​(p)

children.value: operation maps an element $\mathbf{\xi}$ defined in the tangent space at $\mathbf{p}_1$ back to the manifold.

children.alt: Retract operation on a manifold simplified

children.value: An alternative figure to represent the retraction that will be used in the rest of the post, since it shows the interactions between the manifold and the tangent space more explicitly. We can clearly observe that the element $\mathbf{p}$ generated by the retraction is also defined with respect to $\mathbf{p}_1$ on the manifold.
operation does the opposite, and maps an element $\mathbf{p}$ defined with respect to $\mathbf{p}_1$ as an vector $\mathbf{\xi}$ in the tangent space.
Retractions are the fundamental concept to

and to define uncertainties on manifolds. While the former will be covered later in this post with an example, it is useful to explain the latter now. The general idea is that we can define distributions on the tangent space, and map them back on the manifold using the retraction. For instance, we can define a zero-mean Gaussian variable

children.html: η∼Gaussian(0n×1,Σ)\eta \sim Gaussian(\mathbf{0}_{n\times1}, \Sigma)η∼Gaussian(0n×1​,Σ)

children.value: in the tangent space centered at

children.html: p\mathbf{p}p
Gaussian(p1,η):=retractp1(η)Gaussian(\mathbf{p}_1, \mathbf{\eta}) := \text{retract}_{\mathbf{p}_1}(\mathbf{\eta})Gaussian(p1​,η):=retractp1​​(η)

children.value: Using the retraction, we can define Gaussians on the tangent space centered at some element $\mathbf{p}_1$ and map them back on the manifold to construct Gaussians on the manifold with mean $\mathbf{p}_1$ and covariance $\text{Cov}(\eta) = \Sigma$.
Please note that we have defined the retraction
, since this matches the convention used by GTSAM, which coincidently also matches the composition operator for groups. However, in the literature we can find different definitions:
are some examples. Other definitions to define probability distributions on manifolds include
, please refer to their work for further details.
And others are both: Lie groups

children.label: And others are both: Lie groups

children.value: we only need the objects to be differentiable manifolds in order to optimize them
being groups is not a requirement at all
. However, it is important to be aware that
of the objects we deal with are
, which is the formulation generally found in state estimation literature.

children.alt: Lie groups are both groups and differentiable manifolds. They define a tangent space at the identity that allows to represent any object on the manifold through a retraction defined at the identity, known as exponential map, as well as a local operation also at the identity - the logarithm map.

children.value: Lie groups are both groups and differentiable manifolds. They define a tangent space at the identity that allows to represent any object on the manifold through a retraction defined at the identity, known as exponential map, as well as a local operation also at the identity - the logarithm map.
Objects such as rigid-body matrices and quaternions are Lie groups. 2D rigid-body transformations are elements of the

children.html: SE(2)\text{SE(2)}SE(2)

children.value: , while 2D and 3D rotations are from the

children.html: SO(2)\text{SO(2)}SO(2)
SO(3)\text{SO(3)}SO(3)

children.value: respectively. 3D rigid-body transformations are objects of

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)

children.value: and we can use those definitions to define the operations we described before for groups and manifolds:

children.html: T1 T2\mathbf{T}_{1} \ \mathbf{T}_{2}T1​ T2​
I\mathbf{I}I
(T1)−1(\mathbf{T}_{1})^{-1}(T1​)−1

children.value: : The retraction is defined at the tangent space at the identity, which is known as the

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)
retractI(ξ):=Exp(ξ)\text{retract}_{\mathbf{I}}(\mathbf{\xi}) := \text{Exp}(\mathbf{\xi})retractI​(ξ):=Exp(ξ)

children.value: : It is also defined at the identity and known as the

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)
localI:=Log(T1)\text{local}_{\mathbf{I}} := \text{Log}(\mathbf{T}_{1} )localI​:=Log(T1​)

children.value: Please note here that we used

children.html: Log(⋅):=log(⋅)∨\text{Log}(\cdot) := \text{log}( \cdot)^{\vee}Log(⋅):=log(⋅)∨
Exp(⋅):=exp((⋅)∧)\text{Exp}(\cdot):=\text{exp}( (\cdot)^{\wedge})Exp(⋅):=exp((⋅)∧)

children.value: operators for simplicity as used by
, since they are easy to understand under the retractions perspective. Refer to Solà et al. for a more detailed description, including the relationship between tangents spaces and the
In GTSAM, 3D poses are implemented as
objects and we can think of them as

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)

children.value: elements. Therefore, to keep things simple, we will stay using the logarithm map and exponential map to talk about their retraction and local operators. However, GTSAM also allows us to use alternative retractions for some cases, which would be like
to represent poses, such as the

children.html: R3×SO(3)\mathbb{R}^{3}\times\text{SO}(3)R3×SO(3)

children.value: are preserved when applying the local and retract operations
. We will cover a few important ideas using

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)

children.value: , since it is related to our original problem of pose estimation.
First of all, when we talked about
the tangent space defined at the identity
, in physical terms it refers to having a fixed, global frame, which we use to express our poses. Then, when using the
operation defined as the logarithm map of

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)
WξW∈R6_W\mathbf{\xi}_{W} \in \mathbb{R}^{6}W​ξW​∈R6

children.value: ), which is defined in the tangent space

children.html: Wξ=Log(TWBi){_W}\mathbf{\xi} = \text{Log}(\mathbf{T}_{WB_i} )W​ξ=Log(TWBi​​)

children.alt: In this example, the tangent space at the identity represents the world frame, on which any transformation $\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}$ expressed in the world frame can be defined.

children.value: In this example, the tangent space at the identity represents the world frame, on which any transformation $\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}$ expressed in the world frame can be defined.
we can add incremental changes to a transformation using the retraction

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)

children.value: is done with the exponential map as follows:

children.html: TWBi+1=TWBiExp(Biξ)\mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} = \mathbf{T}_{WB_i} \text{Exp}( {_{B_i}}\mathbf{\xi})TWBi+1​​=TWBi​​Exp(Bi​​ξ)

children.value: the increments are defined with respect to a reference frame, but they do not require to specify the resulting frame
. Their meaning (representing a new pose at time

children.html: i+1i+1i+1

children.value: ) is something that we -as users- define but is not explicit in the formulation. (

While we could do it, it can lead to confusions because in this specific case we are representing the pose at the next instant but we can also use retractions to describe corrections to the world frame as we will see in the final post.
The graphical interpretation with the manifold is consistent with our general definition of retractions and frames. Using the exponential map on the right is defining a tangent space at

children.html: TWBi\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}TWBi​​

children.value: , which can be interpreted as a new

children.html: BiB_iBi​

children.value: , which we used to define the increment:

When we add a small increment ${_{B_i}}\mathbf{\xi}$ to the pose $\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}$, the expression $\mathbf{T}_{WB_i} \text{Exp}( {_{B_i}}\mathbf{\xi})$ corresponds to the retraction defined for the tangent space at $\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}$.
The incremental formulation via retractions is also convenient when we have local (body frame) velocity measurements -also known as

children.html: (Biω,Biv)({_{B_i}}\omega, {_{B_i}}{v})(Bi​​ω,Bi​​v)
Biω∈R3,Biv∈R3{_{B_i}}\omega \in \mathbb{R}^{3}, {_{B_i}}v \in \mathbb{R}^{3}Bi​​ω∈R3,Bi​​v∈R3
TWBi+1=TWBiExp([BiωBiv] δt)\mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} = {\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}} \text{Exp}\left( \begin{bmatrix} _{B_i}\omega \\ _{B_i} v \end{bmatrix}\ \delta t \right)TWBi+1​​=TWBi​​Exp([Bi​​ωBi​​v​] δt)
[Biω δtBiv δt]\begin{bmatrix} _{B_i}\omega \ \delta t \\ _{B_i} v \ \delta t\end{bmatrix}[Bi​​ω δtBi​​v δt​]

children.value: represents the tangent vector resulting from time-integrating the velocity, which is map onto the manifold by means of the

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)

children.value: The same formulation can be used to map velocities into increments via retractions/exponential map. In this case, the time increment $\delta t$ controls the length of the curve that is projected on the manifold when we do dead-reckoning.

This last example is also useful to understand the physical meaning of the retraction/local operations in the case of 3D poses, which is not always clear. An interesting aspect of illustrating this with

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE}(3)SE(3)

children.value: is that the meaning also applies if we use rotations only (

children.html: SO(3)\text{SO}(3)SO(3)
SO(2)\text{SO}(2)SO(2)
SE(2)\text{SE}(2)SE(2)

children.value: This figure illustrates the physical meaning of the $\text{SE}(3)$ retraction of the dead-reckoning example. In light blue we show the increment applied to pose ${\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}}$, which generates a
frame. At the right hand side we illustrate the decomposed increment: orientation at the top, and position at the bottom. Each component of the

represents a change with respect to each rotation axis defined by the body pose at ${\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}}$ (rotations with respect to $X$, $Y$ and $Z$ axes, respectively, are shown). When combined, the vector represents an
(right-side, bottom) are easier to interpret because they only represent a shift in position with respect to ${\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}}$'s origin. Since the retraction actually
both orientation and position increments on the manifold, it generates a smooth trajectory as shown on the left-hand side (light blue).
Some remarks on the retract and local operations

children.label: Some remarks on the retract and local operations

children.value: Lastly, we would like to share some important remarks that are not always stated in the math but
can become real issues during the implementation
. First, we need to be careful about
the convention of the order of the components in the retraction/local operation

(yes, more conventions again). Having clarity about the definition that every software or paper uses for these operations, even implicitly, is fundamental to make sense of the quantities we put into our estimation problems and the estimates we extract.
For instance, the definition of the

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)

children.value: convention, i.e, the 6D tangent vector has orientation in the first three coordinates, and translation in the last three

children.html: ξ=(ϕ,ρ)\mathbf{\xi} = (\phi, \rho)ξ=(ϕ,ρ)
ϕ∈R3\phi \in \mathbb{R}^3ϕ∈R3
ρ∈R3\rho \in \mathbb{R}^3ρ∈R3

children.value: the translational ones. On the other hand,

children.html: (x,y,θ)(x, y, \theta)(x,y,θ)

children.value: This is also ties the definition of the covariances

objects, for instance, we must define covariance matrices that match the definition and meaning of the tangent vectors. In fact, the upper-left block must encode orientation covariances, i.e, our degree of uncertainty for each rotation axis, while the bottom-right encodes position covariances:

children.html: [ΣϕϕΣϕρΣϕρTΣρρ]\left[\begin{matrix} \Sigma_{\phi\phi} & \Sigma_{\phi\rho} \\ \Sigma_{\phi\rho}^{T} & \Sigma_{\rho\rho} \end{matrix}\right][Σϕϕ​ΣϕρT​​Σϕρ​Σρρ​​]

children.value: This is of paramount importance because, for example, the previous covariance matrix does not match the convention used in ROS to store the covariances in
. Similar issues can arise when using different libraries or software, so we must be aware of their conventions. Our advice is
to always check the retraction/exponential map definition
if not stated in the documentation.
Now we can return to our original estimation problem using rigid-body transformations. Let us recall that we defined the following process model given by odometry measurements:

children.html: TWBi+1=TWBi ΔTBiBi+1Ni\mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} = \mathbf{T}_{WB_i} \ \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}} \mathbf{N}_iTWBi+1​​=TWBi​​ ΔTBi​Bi+1​​Ni​

children.value: We needed to define the noise

children.html: Ni\mathbf{N}_iNi​

children.value: as a Gaussian noise, but it was a

children.html: 4×44\times44×4

children.value: When isolating the noise to create the residual, we ended up with a matrix expression, not vector one as we needed in our estimation framework.
We can identify now that our poses are objects of

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)

children.value: , hence we can use the tools we just defined.
The first problem of defining the noise appropriately is solved by using probability distributions on manifolds as we described before. We define
a zero-mean Gaussian in the tangent space at

children.html: ΔTBiBi+1\Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}}ΔTBi​Bi+1​​

children.value: and retract it onto the manifold

children.html: TWBi+1=TWBi ΔTBiBi+1Exp(Bi+1η)\mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} = \mathbf{T}_{WB_i} \ \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}} \text{Exp}(_{B_{i+1}}\mathbf{\eta})TWBi+1​​=TWBi​​ ΔTBi​Bi+1​​Exp(Bi+1​​η)

children.alt: Defining noise for the relative increment.

children.value: Graphical interpretation of the definition of the noise, which is defined in frame $B_{i+1}$ and mapped using the retraction.

children.html: Bi+1η∼Gaussian(06×1, Bi+1Σ){_{B_{i+1}}}\eta \sim Gaussian(\mathbf{0}_{6\times1},\ _{B_{i+1}}\Sigma)Bi+1​​η∼Gaussian(06×1​, Bi+1​​Σ)

children.value: . Please note that in order to match our right-hand convention,
the covariance we use must be defined in the body frame at time

children.html: i+1i+1i+1
Bi+1B_{i+1}Bi+1​

children.value: the covariance matrix must follow the same ordering defined by the retraction as we mentioned before
Having solved the first problem, we can now focus on the residual definition. We can isolate the noise as we did before, which holds:

children.html: Exp(Bi+1η)=ΔTBiBi+1−1 TWBi−1 TWBi+1\text{Exp}( {_{B_{i+1}}}\mathbf{\eta}) = \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}}^{-1}\ \mathbf{T}_{WB_i}^{-1} \ \mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}}Exp(Bi+1​​η)=ΔTBi​Bi+1​−1​ TWBi​−1​ TWBi+1​​

children.value: operator of the manifold on both sides to
map the residual to the tangent space

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)

Bi+1η=Log(ΔTBiBi+1−1 TWBi−1 TWBi+1)_{B_{i+1}}\mathbf{\eta} = \text{Log}\left( \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}}^{-1}\ \mathbf{T}_{WB_i}^{-1} \ \mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} \right)Bi+1​​η=Log(ΔTBi​Bi+1​−1​ TWBi​−1​ TWBi+1​​)

children.value: Since the noise is defined in the tangent space, both sides denote vector expressions in

children.html: R6\mathbb{R}^{6}R6

children.value: . Both also correspond to zero-mean Gaussians, hence the right-hand side can be used as a proper factor in our estimation framework. In fact, the expression on the right side is
the same used in GTSAM to define the

children.alt: Defining noise for the relative increment.

children.value: The Between residual, illustrated. On the left hand side, we have the corresponding transformations involved in the computation expressed on the manifold. Since the error (in red) is also defined on the manifold, it is not described by a straight line. However, by applying the local operation, given by the logarithm map for $\text{SE(3)}$, we can map it to to the tangent space at $\Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}}$, which is a vector space (right). The error itself should lie within the Gaussian we created using the noise $_{B_{i+1}}\mathbf{\eta}$, which denotes the noise of the odometry model.
We must also keep in mind here that by using the
the residual vector will follow the same ordering

objects, it will encode orientation error in the first 3 components, while translation error in the last ones. In this way, if we write the expanded expression for the Gaussian factor, we can notice that all the components are weighted accordingly by the inverse covariance as we reviewed before (orientation first, and then translation):

children.html: rbetween(TWBi,TWBi+1)=∣∣Log(ΔTBiBi+1−1 TWBi−1 TWBi+1)∣∣Σi2=Log(ΔTBiBi+1−1 TWBi−1 TWBi+1)T Σi−1Log(ΔTBiBi+1−1 TWBi−1 TWBi+1)\begin{split} \mathbf{r}_{\text{between}}(\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}, \mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}}) &= \left|\left| \text{Log}\left( \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}}^{-1}\ \mathbf{T}_{WB_i}^{-1} \ \mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} \right)\right|\right|^{2}_{\Sigma_i} \\ & = \text{Log}\left( \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}}^{-1}\ \mathbf{T}_{WB_i}^{-1} \ \mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} \right)^{T} \ \Sigma_i^{-1} \\ & \qquad \qquad \qquad \text{Log}\left( \Delta\mathbf{T}_{B_{i} B_{i+1}}^{-1}\ \mathbf{T}_{WB_i}^{-1} \ \mathbf{T}_{WB_{i+1}} \right) \end{split}rbetween​(TWBi​​,TWBi+1​​)​=∣∣​∣∣​Log(ΔTBi​Bi+1​−1​ TWBi​−1​ TWBi+1​​)∣∣​∣∣​Σi​2​=Log(ΔTBi​Bi+1​−1​ TWBi​−1​ TWBi+1​​)T Σi−1​Log(ΔTBi​Bi+1​−1​ TWBi​−1​ TWBi+1​​)​

children.value: The factor is now a nonlinear vector expression that can be solved using the nonlinear optimization techniques we presented before. In fact, GTSAM already implements Jacobians for the
operator of all the objects implemented, which simplifies the process. However, there are subtle differences that we must clarify.
First, since the factor defines a residual in the tangent space at the current linearization point, the optimization itself is executed
in the tangent space defined in the current linearization point
. This means that when we linearize the factors and build the normal equations, the increment

children.html: BiδTk{_{B_i}}\delta\mathbf{T}^{k}Bi​​δTk

children.value: we compute lies in the tangent space.
For this reason, we need to update the variables
using the retraction. For example, for

children.html: SE(3)\text{SE(3)}SE(3)
T~WBik+1=TWBikExp(BiδTk)\mathbf{\tilde{T}}_{WB_i}^{k+1} = \mathbf{T}_{WB_i}^k \text{Exp}( {_{B_i}}\delta\mathbf{T}^{k} )T~WBi​k+1​=TWBi​k​Exp(Bi​​δTk)

children.value: The second important point, is that the covariance that we can recover from the information matrix,
will be also defined in the tangent space around the linearization point, following the convention of the retraction
. It means that if our information matrix at the current linearization point is given by:

children.html: Σk+1=((Hk)T(Σk)−1Hk)−1\Sigma^{k+1} = ((\mathbf{H}^k)^{T} (\Sigma^{k})^{-1} \mathbf{H}^k)^{-1}Σk+1=((Hk)T(Σk)−1Hk)−1

children.value: Then, the corresponding distribution of the solution around the current linearization point

children.html: TWBik+1\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}^{k+1}TWBi​k+1​
Gaussian(TWBik+1,Σk+1):=TWBik+1Exp(Biηk+1)Gaussian(\mathbf{T}_{WB_i}^{k+1}, \Sigma^{k+1}) := \mathbf{T}_{WB_i}^{k+1} \text{Exp}( {_{B_i}}\eta^{k+1} )Gaussian(TWBi​k+1​,Σk+1):=TWBi​k+1​Exp(Bi​​ηk+1)
Biηk+1∼Gaussian(06×1,BiΣk+1){_{B_i}}\eta^{k+1} \sim Gaussian(\mathbf{0}_{6\times1}, {_{B_i}}\Sigma^{k+1})Bi​​ηk+1∼Gaussian(06×1​,Bi​​Σk+1)

children.value: . As a consequence of the convention on the retraction,
the resulting covariance is expressed in the body frame as well, and uses orientation-then-translation for the ordering of the covariance matrix

In this second part we extended the estimation framework presented previously by introducing the reference frames in an explicit manner into our notation, which helped to understand the meaning of the quantities.
We also reviewed the concept of groups of manifolds. We discussed that manifolds are the essential concept to generalize the optimization framework and probability distributions as defined in GTSAM.

conventions which, while not standard, allowed us to identify different formulations that can be found in the literature to operate groups and manifolds. By explicitly stating that GTSAM uses a right-hand convention for the composition of groups as well as retractions on manifolds we could identify the frames used to define the variables, as well as the covariance we obtain from the solution via

Additionally, the definition of the local and retract operations also have direct impact on the ordering of the covariance matrices, which also varies depending on the object. For instance, we discussed that
. This is particularly important when we want to use GTSAM quantities with different software, such as ROS, which use a
convention for their 3D pose structures for instance (
will cover some final remarks regarding the conventions we defined and applications of the
of a Lie group, which is quite useful to properly transform covariance matrices defined for poses.
